name: Rajasthani Kadhi
history: Rajasthani Kadhi is a part of Rajasthani cuisine, known for its spicy and tangy taste. It differs from other regional variations of Kadhi in India due to its distinct preparation and flavor.
description: This version of Kadhi is a yogurt-based curry made with gram flour, spices, and often includes pakoras (fried fritters). It's known for its comforting and tangy flavor, usually served with rice or chapati.

instructions.title: Prepare the Kadhi Mixture
instructions.description: In a mixing bowl, whisk together sour yogurt, gram flour, turmeric powder, red chili powder, and water until smooth.

instructions.title: Cook the Tadka
instructions.description: Heat ghee in a pan. Add mustard seeds, cumin seeds, fenugreek seeds, asafoetida, and curry leaves. Let them splutter.

instructions.title: Simmer the Kadhi
instructions.description: Add the yogurt mixture to the pan. Bring to a boil, then simmer on low heat for about 30 minutes, stirring occasionally. Season with salt.

instructions.title: Garnish and Serve
instructions.description: Garnish with fresh cilantro. Serve hot with rice or chapati.

tips: Make sure the kadhi is not too thick or thin; adjust the consistency with water.
Continuously stir the kadhi while cooking to prevent it from curdling.
variations: Add pakoras (fried gram flour fritters) to the kadhi for a heartier dish.
For a spicier kadhi, increase the amount of red chili powder.

storage.shelfLife: Can be refrigerated for up to 2 days.
storage.instructions: Store in an airtight container and reheat before serving.

reheatingInstructions: Reheat on the stove or in a microwave, stirring occasionally.
presentationTips: Serve in a traditional Indian serving bowl, garnished with cilantro.
Accompany with a side of steamed basmati rice or warm flatbread.
